title: 6mm Tube Makergear M2 Filament Guide Support Arm for 1.75mm filament

description.text:
Two sizes, 6mm works great with 6mm OD teflon tubing which I highly recommend as it will always provide the least restriction even when using 1.75 mm filament. If your filament happens to have any bends when coming off the spool that puts restriction on the extruder as its being pulled through a small tube, give the extruder an easier time by using the 6mm OD tubing.

Buy the tubing from Mc-Master Carr, this is known good quality tubing, unlike the unknown stuff you can get on Ebay. Only $2.75 a foot as of March 2017.
https://www.mcmaster.com/#52335K34

The other legacy file is designed for the 3mm tubing that is stock on the makergear M2.

Also included is a simple adapter that allows the 6mm tubing to attach to this extruder:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:344950

Youtube video covering my various Makergear M2 Mods:

title: Bed Leveling Constant Tension Easy Adjustment Fix for Makergear M2 3D Printer

description.text:
AHHH!!! the screw lock system that comes stock on the makergear M2 is anything but fun to adjust ;)

Anyway this solves that :) All you need in addition to the stock bolt and nut is a small spring that fits over the 4mm screw and is between 10 - 20mm long.

You pretension the spring a little, then insert the nut in the top - constant pressure is then put on the screw holding it in place, fine adjustment is possible with just your hand :) and the nut will never turn because of the spring tension and the arm which locks the screw precisely to the side of the linear bearing.

This will work great with the stock mechanical switch, but for even higher end stop repeat-ability you should consider buying a $2 optical end stop switch like I have from ebay, see my other files for the 3d printable mount. This combo makes ultra consistent bed adhesion possible.
Optical Endstop: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1195834

Youtube video covering my various Makergear M2 Mods:
https://youtu.be/jD6ZTcCd0j8

By - http://www.easybotics.com/
And - http://hilo90mhz.com/

author: kos42

description.text: Tetrahedron

I designed this Quadcopter with the intention of making it quicker to assemble than other DIY kits. Here are the features:

ARMS 

4 Arms and Main plate form a single structure.  No need to  bolt the arms and main plate together.  
Arms desgined for 3100KV Motor with  5 MM shaft and  M2 screws  
Arms have 2 pairs of slots for routing a cable tie.  
40 MM max width of arm to accomodate upto 6A ESCs  
Arm thickness is 2 MM supported by a 5 MM wide and 10 MM thick under skirt. Skirt adds rigidity to the arms while also acting as a landing gear with wide load distribution.

Main Plate 

60 MM wide and 200 MM long main plate for placing Micro FPV camera, VTX, FC, RX and a 2S battery in the same plane  
18 M3 holes  evenly spread across the  body for mounting accessories.  Outer holes form a 30.5 square for mounting a CC3D board.  
Horizontal slits for rounting wires and velcros.  
Supported by 5MM  wide and 10 MM thick under skirt.   Adds rigidity to the 2 MM thick plate while also acting as a landing skid.

Accessories:

  • 10 Degree tilted FPV Camera Mount
  • Tail for adding an Rx or its antenna

Note that this is intended to be a not-fast quadcopter: aimed at FPV beginners. My goal is to create something like a Blade 180 QX with the power of brushless motors. I will be assembling this on my own when the print is ready.

Added 3100KV Motors with 2 MM Bullet connectors. Will be using 6A ESCs on this.

The Arms/Wings are warped a bit. More so on the left side. Hope it doesn't affect the flight too much.

author: Stefaans

description.text: I made this for my giant legoman, as he was missing something in his life. It is a simple design, but looks great. Printed it flat side down, using 0.3 layers and 25% fill. Please feel free to improve at your leisure.

The HC-SR04 is a great little ultrasonic sensor that is really cheap, and easy to use in projects.

This case is designed to be used with cable ties so the sensor can easily to mounted to sticks and other objects.

This is a pretty simple design in 3 parts. The parts only take about 15 minutes each to print.

The front face needs to be glued to the middle section - I like using Araldite 5 minute glue as it works well with ABS. I made the front face separate so I could print it at a higher resolution to the middle and back sections. I also find it easier/faster printing simpler parts that glue together rather than trying to print one big complex part.

The case design requires that right angle male header pins are used on the HC-SR04, facing forwards. For a cable I like using 4-core telephone wire with a 4-way female header pin which fits nicely into the slot on the underside of the case.

The sensor should fit snugly onto the back plate without the need for screws to hold it in place. You can use just the back plate on it's own to hold the sensor so print this part first.

Enjoy.

In case you're wondering, the project I'm using these sensors on outside is a system to detect my neighbors cat, that likes to spray the door of my house. I set up 2 sensors up either side of the door, connected to an arduino, and a water solenoid value to turn my sprinkler system on when triggered.

comments.text: When designing cases for these sensors, is it necessary to shape the case angling toward the sensors as you did? Would having it come directly to the side of the sensor without that beveling affect the reading? Or is it more of a "better safe than sorry" situation? I've noticed some designs have the metal protruding from their cases by a few mm.
comments.author: gravityisweak

comments.text: I did that just to make it look more like eyes, it was purely for aesthetics rather than being functional. You could easily test what is optimal by cutting some holes in cardboard, and varying the amount by which the sensor protrudes. I suspect it won't make much difference, the material of the object you are trying to detect is more important. Hard surfaces reflect the sound better than fluffy objects like cats, or soft toys.
comments.author: gravityisweak

title: Hotend open support for double 30mm fans

description.text:
Just a way to support two 30mm fans on double hotends without limiting to the type of hotends (should work for most types). You should use BIG zip ties in order to fix it.

It is open, meaning it does not enclose the hotends for better ventilation, but depending on the design of your printer that﻿ could also mean that it throws a lot of air on an ABS print, which is undesirable for it might cause warp.

BOM:

  • 8 M3x10 screws
  • 8 M3 nuts
  • 2 40cm zip ties
  • 2 30mm fans

You should press the M3 nuts in their cavities (don't forget to activate XY/horizontal compensation if your slicer have it so that the holes don't become too tight) then attach the fans by inserting the screws. Since it becomes so steady, you don't even have to use all screws - if you notice the pictures, I don't.

Then just hold it to your double hotend then insert the zip ties into the lateral tabs.

title: Star Wars : The Force Awakens - Captain Phasma Helmet

description.text:
This is the Helmet of Captain Phasma one of the new Villains from the upcoming Star Wars the force Awakens. I had not seen any Captain Phasma files here on thingiverse and after My First Order Stormtrooper Helmet has been Popular I decided this should be next. Much like the First Order Stormtrooper Helmet but slightly more Edgy and engraved around the edges.

Once again this Helmet comes Cut up into 8 pieces designed to print on a Robo 3D R1 however I have also included 2 versions of the Full Helmet so you can Slice it however fits your printer best. I have left the pieces in chunks as I like to cut out the inside of the helmet to best fit my head, or possible just to leave it full if it will be a display piece (also is easier to print on my machine). The files are small and when you load them they are designed to be scaled up by a factor of 150, or you can measure and adjust according to your head size.

Once I have completed printing this and prepping it I will upload Pictures of the finished product. Please note this is not a High Res version and will require sanding and finishing Post Print. If you would like to use this Model to refine and smooth into a High Res Version please feel free to do so and make sure you send me a copy!

comments.text: Really nice addition to an awesome project.  Just starting to get mine printed.  How much difference did you notice adding the angle iron piece?  Also, what rods are you using for the frame?  I like the white.  Are those powder coated or something?  Just wondering how well they hold up and if they are smoother than the regular EMT stock.  Final question, what did you use for the cable chain?  Sorry for all the questions, just really like your setup.  Thanks.
comments.author: danzca6

comments.text:
The aluminum angle dosent improve strength, it is there for the cable chain to run along and attach to.
The tubing I am using is closet rail (all I could get at the time), it has a white coating on it, I think its powder coated but poor quality, I would NOT reccomend it as the coating has started falling off in places thereby reducing the diameter of the tube and giving a rough surface for the bearings.
The cable chain is http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11978 by rotoscan
Cheers Bob.

author: bwarren

title: Spring-Loaded Extruder CTC Replicator Dual fit

description.text:
This is the makerbot spring-loaded extruder, but customised to fit the CTC Replicator Dual Printer. It uses the Gear of the original extruder.
I also made the bearing fixed with a screw because the original plastic piece looked way to weak.The cover fits a normal M3 screw head. You need a 8 mm M3 screw for the bearing, 16 mm M3 screw for the lever, 5 mm M3 countersunk screw (you can use the original and cut it) for the second screw to the motor. You also need 3 M3 washers. One is for the screw at the lever. Two for the bearing (you have to cut a bit of the material on the cover piece to fit perfect). The spring has to be 10 mm in diameter. I used 32mm x 10mm and cut it to 30mm x 10mm. Then it has pretty hard pressure.

When you install the extruder you should stick a bit of tape to the back of the heat sink which isolate the metal parts from each other, because they will make very annoying noises while printing. But make sure the tape is not between the alu block in the bottom and the heat sink, because than it won't cool it right.

Because it got requested, here are the STL files of both extruders.
Each extruder consists of the three parts:

  • main
  • lever
  • cover

you can download each part separate.

When you want to print ABS in a heated closed chamber you should print the extruder in ABS, because PLA will deform itself after a while. PLA worked for month for me when only printing PLA in open printer.

comments.text: I didn't have that problem, so I think my printer came with a 10mm bearing, but I don't want do disassemble my extruder right now.
comments.author: LightbeamZ

comments.text: The bearing from mine is too big http://i.imgur.com/1W7xWAe.jpg What is the OD of yours? Mine is 12mm. From what I've found there may be 2 different bearings that came with CTC printers. 10mm and 12mm.
comments.author: Woraug

comments.text: Sorry I don't know which size the bearing is. It is the original one of the CTC machine. It has to be bigger then the one of the Makerbot because I had to make the hole for the bearing bigger to fit the CTC one. Its not a typical bearing because it uses a V-shape.
comments.author: LightbeamZ

comments.text: What size is the bearing on this thing?  A 624zz bearing is too big.
comments.author: rj11

comments.text: I think it will work, because it is a remix of the original makerbot extruder and the axis of the bearing is the same. I only made a hole in that spot to put a screw instead of the plastic bearing axis. But you will need a flat bearing which pushes against the filament because on that gear the grove is in the gear and not the bearing.
comments.author: LightbeamZ

comments.text:
LightbeamZ, Will this work with MK8 Drive Gear http://reprap.me/mk8.html ? Also can you upload the STL files?
Thank you

comments.text: It uses the gear and the bearing from the original extruder. I customized it to fit the original parts. You only need the screws, washers and the spring I mentioned in the info text.

This model was printed on a Makerbot Rep2 using Wingcommander's 100 micron RepG profile. Print-o-matic settings are 20% infill, with supports, 3 shells, 80/150 feedrates at 230C.

To roughly test filament thickness.
It starts at 3.25mm and goes down to 1.5mm in 0.25mm increments.

This is a remix of the Dewalt 611 Deflector and Dust Shoe uploaded by vishnubob; all work and credit goes to him, I simply modified his files by increasing the diameter of the collet hole and mirroring the mounting holes to allow for different router orientations.
3D printed on a Makerbot 2 :)

Needed a simple holder that can be used with different width spools.
Since my printer is fixed on a wooden board, the solution was easy...

(need to cleanup the wires.... but the roll doesn't get near them, so it should be safe)

Uses 2x 8mm rods and 4 x 22mm ball bearings.

(includes STEP file if anyone needs minor changes)

Need to mount your new tweeters on your 'A' pillar or window corner plate. but they just don't quite point to the right positions?
what you need is a Tweeter Pod to get that sound in the sweet spot for your system.

Print this inverted so the flare is at the top.
Only light infill is required 5% or so
Print in any resolution (finer will produce smoother blot up angle face)
pictures shown are only low res and printed in 30 mins including raft and support.
Printing with support will give a better flare finish.
You may need to glue your tweeter in place depending on it's mounting interface.

comments.text:
You show the tweeterpod here on a part of an Audi A4 8k (when i am right). Do you think it´s possible to scan the part of Audi and print it with the whole with the speakers facing the driver´s seat position? I would like to use some Helix Speakers S801 competition.
Best regards, Kevin

pane_size = large
hole_diameter = 10
text_reverse = no

Recommended for printing with ABS or PETG.
Support is recommended.

This is a precise fit for the following Chinese Gimbal.
http://www.goodluckbuy.com/dji-phantom-brushless-gimbal-camera-mount-w-motor-and-controller-for-gopro3-fpv-aerial-photography.html

It will also move the Gimbal/camera forward a little to avoid the signal/power outputs and also avoid getting the legs in view of the camera. I have tested this out, and it seems to work perfectly.

Any questions or suggestions, feel free to leave them in the comments.

comments.text:
The gimbal is mounted quite to the front (what i really like).
Do you have any issue with the center of gravity?
Can the Nova/CX20 compensate this easily?
comments.author: mr_cg

comments.text: Well not quite a good fix for mine. I am going to do a remix.
comments.author: JCPhlux

comments.text: That's unfortunate, but after all, you do have a different Gimbal.  I wish you luck in the Remix.
comments.author: JCPhlux

comments.text: I was just about to design this very thing. I don't have the exact gimbal but they look very close. I am alittle worries about it being a snap fit. Has this been an issue at all?
comments.author: JCPhlux

comments.text: I haven't had an issue yet.  It's quite a secure fit.  If you remove the gimbal often, I could see wear on the clips being an issue.  If it gets worn out... Just print a new one.
comments.author: JCPhlux

comments.text: I  recall the CX-20 having only two nuts for the gimbal, in the pic those places are not used, how did you fix the gimbal to the quad? I see the bolts but I do not recall nuts in those places.
comments.author: meirm

comments.text: My CX -20 has 4 mounting screw points for a gimbal.  Image of it that I found online as an example.

author: hackeria

description.text:
This is the final version of this. It has spikes now, but some of the other details were removed. This part was made with Tinkercad. Edit the part online at:
https://tinkercad.com/p/acc065a93bdce4af Old version: This part was made with Tinkercad. Edit the part online at: https://tinkercad.com/p/acc04741366d812a

I got tired of all these fan holders that were either an entire case, or were meant for fans larger than 40mm. So, I took the opportunity to create a very simple and basic fan holder for the Sanguino. Check out the pictures, they will tell you everything you need to know. I positioned the best part of the airflow directly over the Z-axis stepper drivers, because the Z-stepper driver tends to overheat the quickest because it has to drive 2 motors instead of one on my Reprap Air 2. I hope this is of any use for others.
  • Marinus

Printed this on 0.25mm layer height, you are free to do what you want, but this layer height is fine for me because of the thicknesses in the part are mostly round figures height-wise.  
The parts are both placed in the STL ready-to-print.

author: Reuben_M

title: Rostock Max V2 Spool Spin Smoother

description.text: The spool holder is square at the top so each time the extruder pulled in filament, the machine would jerk a bit. This solved that problem.

This solved this problem for material spools that are large enough to fit on it (Matter Hackers filament is shown here). The mouse ears are to ensure no warping when using ABS. Just clip them off and super glue the two supports to the bed, and super glue the rounded spool holder to the support plate. Pictures shown to prove that this works. It was printed with the Rostock Max V2 I just finished building.

title: Faucet knob cover
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I don't know if I would make this again. I made it in PLA so it would match the acrylic sink knobs, but the shrinkage / variability of nozzle position / etc made it difficult to maintain consistency. I probably made this 4 or 5 times before I got the dimensions figured out. A little hot glue might help, though. Here are the settings that I used: Temp: 200C
Build Platform Temp: 110C.
100% fill.
Nozzle location: Eyeballed to "close enough." The color is from Sharpie marker that I painted on clear PLA before it went through the extruder. The colors aren't rich, but they serve their purpose. I've also attached the source files, becuase I expect you'll want to modify this some. If you look around at them, you'll see a tapered hole I put in the bottom to allow for the screw. This didn't work out too well, but it did thin out the plastic a little bit so I could waller it out with a drill bit. Yes, I wrote "waller." Don't judge me. EDIT: 7/2/11: Use the second stl file. the one wth the tabs. I think it will work better, but I haven't tested it. EDIT: 7/5/11: This doesn't work. At least not with PLA. If I get some time, I'll try it with ABS.
Print. Try to install on knob. Scale part a little bit. Repeat.

comments.text: I need two of these so bad.
comments.author: charlespax

comments.text: Actually, try the second one. I think it would work better.
comments.author: charlespax

comments.text: Well, good luck. I'm working on a better design, but I won't be able to print it for a week or so. I don't know if I'd go for these or not. There's too tight of a tolerance to meet. Thanks!

The Galata Tower (Galata Kulesi in Turkish) — called Christea Turris (the Tower of Christ in Latin) by the Genoese — is a medieval stone tower in the Galata/Karaköy quarter of Istanbul, Turkey, just to the north of the Golden Horn's junction with the Bosphorus. One of the city's most striking landmarks, it is a high, cone-capped cylinder that dominates the skyline and offers a panoramic vista of Istanbul's historic peninsula and its environs.

My version of fully 3d-printable filament spool holder.

Idea come from CreativeTools

I just remade it to be a bit more efficient (less plastic and time spent printing) and that it can be fitted on Prusa i3 frame easily.

22.3.2016 UPDATE!!!

-added v1.5
-added wheels and spindle for 1.75mm filament axes
-added free filament holder

I decided to upload v1.5 instead of new v2, because it did not meet my expectations and perform worse than v1. I have just a little spare time so it may take a while till I finish it.

v1.5 is just tweaked update of current parts
-wheels and spindle have bigger holes so they shouldn't need sanding.
-spindle has a bit taller base so wheels doesn't look out ot top and doesn't interfere with filament spool and also a bit wider cone so bigger diameter spools will fit.
-holder has octagonal pins instead of sqare ones so they fit in round holes more easily
-body has reduced height to save time and filament
-cone has larger hole so it should fit more easily and lifted bottom edge so its easier to take it off from printbed.

All new parts aren't tested so if you find any mistakes, please report them in coments or try to print older version of part.

I printed it from PLA, layer height 0,2mm, speed around 40-50 mm/s on my Prusa i3.
Some parts may need a bit of sanding to fit.
Wheel shafts are made from 3mm filament.
If you have troubles puting it together, look on this video to understand (original CreativeTools video)

8/19/15: Updated with Tool-Holder files:

  • Butterfly needle/syringe holder
  • Dino-Camera holder
  • Generic flat sided tool holder
  • Flat top tool posts
  • Splash screen holder

    This is a project using parts from an old lamp. There's an image of the Donor-lamp in the list above. The lamp had a few "goose necks" and cost about 10$ on sale, at a big box. The idea was to use these goose-necks to hold tools on a work surface.

First, remove the light fixtures and pull out the wires. Take off the stand. All that remains is the goose-necks and the metal ring where they are all attached.

Second, make a small platform from scrap wood or drill a hole in your desk. You'll need a 3/8" bolt with two washers and a nut.

Next, 3D print the "helpingHands.stl" file, then attach the goose-neck base to the 3D printed support (or workbench).

Finally, start developing your own set of custom tool holders for the ends of the goose-necks. Maybe a camera holder or some wire spools, solder, alligator clamps, LED light, magnifying glass, a fan; whatever helps.

You can use the hollow center of the goose-necks to run USB power, air lines or even a vacuum line. Anything really. The holes in the wooden platform are for additional holders or maybe a cut-out for a parts tray...

Have fun!

title: Large Seven-Segment Display Sized for 5mm LEDs

description.text:
Here's a 3D printable, large seven-segment display that fits 5mm LEDs!

This was designed to fit with Printrbot Play 3D printer, which has a smaller build dimension that renders it incapable of printing other large seven-segment displays.

Here's the Tinkercad links:
Display Case: https://tinkercad.com/things/brqCLkZRv4s
Segment: https://tinkercad.com/things/boqS9T1wq6t

Print seven of the segments, preferably in a natural PLA so that the LED light can shine through more easily.

Print one display case. If printing with a Printrbot Play, you'll have to disable the skirt so that the display case fits on the printer bed. I recommend a 15% infill.

Note that you cannot scale the display and it's segements within your 3D printer software, otherwise the 5mm LEDs won't fit.

For build instructions on a breadboard and some software, check out https://electrothoughts.wordpress.com/2015/09/11/project-xl-seven-segment-display/

description.text:
Wall mount brackets for Verizon's Quantum Gateway router seem to be hard to come by. Some say they're supposed to come with the install, but often do not. Removing the base, you can attach the router to this piece with the alignment posts and the center screw. Unlike the base, this can be mounted left- or right-facing. The wall mount slots will fit over most flat or pan head wood screws, and you can mount it sideways or upside down as well.

STL base units should be millimeters. As a check, the center-to-center distance for the wall-mount holes is 80mm.

Made in Solidworks, converted to STL. Then fabbed on a Stratasys FDT Titan in polycarbonate.

Note that this may be difficult to fab in a single material builder with no sacrificial support material. May be able to work around this by replacing the alignment posts with through holes for pan-head machine screws. they may be the right size to substitute for the posts.

author: Vitsika

title: PVC downtube carrier For Bubble Bucket

description.text:
I designed this thing to eliminate the aluminum extrusions in the bubble bucket assembly design, and use something I had laying around - 1.5" PVC pipe. Print in a pair, and this PVC clamp will hug the lip on a standard 5 gallon bucket from lowes (or home depot i assume) and clamp around a vertical PVC pipe with 1/4-20 bolts to suspend the bubble belt assembly. In the vertical PVC pipe, you can easily cut a slot for the bubble bucket gear on bottom, and mount the drive motor on the top.

Modeled in Inches so scale up by 25.4

UPDATED: Added motor mount with radius to fit PVC downtube

Update2: Added chamfers to drive and idler gears to prevent chain from walking and jamming. Much more reliable now.
Motor drive gear hole was slightly off center and small for my shaft coupler so I made it larger (.26" i think??) and re-centered.

comments.text: Flipping clever!!! great addition!
comments.author: scratchhax

comments.text: Thanks! Yea the bottom sprocket has no wobble at all! Still waiting on my gear reduced motor to see how well that mounts with the round pipe though. May need to redo that motor bracket or something....

title: High Resolution Herringbone gears for Greg's Wade Reloaded extruder.

description.text:
Dimensionally the gears are identical to Stoffel15's herringbone/fishbone gears and still a 9:47 ratio. The only changes are a larger number of facets/faces on the parts. So when printed at very high resolution or scaled up, the sides of any circles will not be as visible. I made some minor changes to the scad files to that others could easily change the resolution on there own gears. Originally I got the files from Lulzbot (http://download.lulzbot.com/AO-101/hardware/printed_parts/source/), but I think those files were derived from Stoffel15's, jonaskueling's, and Greg Frost's work. For the pictures of the printed small herringbone gear I used the original unedited file I downloaded to create a low res stl. For both the low res and high res prints are using the same slic3r configs.The reason for the waviness on the low res gear is the speed that the gear were printed at at lower speeds the low res gear does not look as wazy but still has noticeable number of "sides". Where as with the high res gear, high speeds did not really affect the quality. Number of facets for
Original large herringbone gear:5478
Highres large herringbone gear:11209 Original small herringbone gear:744
Highres large herringbone gear:2024

author: 1337Maker

description.text:
When I've swapped shell in my Phantom 1 making it capable of transporting bigger batteries i forgot about basic problem. In Phantom 1 i had a door on hinges but Phantom 2 doesn't have those.

There aren't many free (!) doors to choose from in internet so i have decided to make my own and this is what a came up with.

Specification:

  • 2cm length,
  • almost perfect fit (see pictures),
  • latches preventing horizontal movement,
  • integrated support for latches in 3d model.

For what it came out it is sufficient for my needs.
I know it is not perfect and many upgrades can be done so feel free to use it as a base.

There is a chance I will make upgrades in the future.

Printed in PLA 195/65 Celsius.
50% infill - there is some on bottom corners and latches. If you feel it is to low make it 100%. Overall time will not increase dramatically.

Because it has support you will need some little files and/or dremel.

title: Store Front Music Solenoid Thwacker Unit - Mechanics

description.text:
This is a work in progress for improving the mechanics of the thwackers in our Store Front Music Project. The thwackers mechanism houses a solenoid that when pulsed with current throws the attached lever arm. The lever is made from an old plastic clothes hanger. The general steps required make the thwacker are
  • Download the files
  • Cut on Laser Cutter
  • Assemble
  • Mount on pegboard
    • Please also see "Store Front Music Solenoid Thwacker Unit - Electronics"

Assemble: http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-make-a-CRASH-Space-Store-Front-Music-t/ In context: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zugpKxPxAE8 Features:
  • It can go into 1-inch spaced peg board and then has an inch to slide for fine tuning
  • Removable mallets (white coat hanger part) for transport
    • Things you might want to change:
  • longer screws with a nut to mount solenoids so they can be tightened from the bottom

comments.text: We'll post a video when you can see them in action.  As a working definition to propose to the OED - Thwacker:  Mechanized lever arm capable of hitting other items with a sound that is similar to the phonetic pronunciation of THWACK.

author: focuslearning

title: Rostock Max V2 E3D V6 Ultimate layer fan shroud

description.text:
This cooling rig dramatically increased my print quality. I can now print overhangs over 45 degrees cleanly and consistently.
As you can see in the CFD simulation, the 3 air ducts channel the air exactly down the center. This maximizes the cooling of the printed section. This effect can clearly be felt on the actual printer.

Installing the E3D V6 on the Rostock max is easy, but thanks to its compact design it's hard to fit a layer fan. I've tried about 10 different shroud designs, fans etcetera and found that either they didn't fit, or they would not blow in the right direction. Finally decided to design my own cooling rig.
I've edited the layerfan shroud design by dreyfusduke to fit the E3D V6 with the effector plate either inverted or normal. It cools the prints instantly, but when using 3 50x10 radial fans the fan speed setting should not exceed 70% or nozzle temperature will drop dramatically.
You can now easily tune the cooling to your needs. Either remove all fans for maximum print speed, use just one for medium overhangs, or use three for maximum cooling for the most complicated prints.
The original part by dreyfusduke can be found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:614597

-- Update --
With the original Rostock V2 U-joints, these shrouds need some sanding/cutting to create enough clearance with the U-joints.
I now have the new SeeMeCNC ball-joint upgrade with the new effector plate, and these shrouds still work great with the new design!

Print the layer fan shroud 3 times in ABS.
No screws or glue required, slides snugly on the effector plate mounting lips.

Print settings:
Printer: Rostock Max V2
Material: ABS black
Nozzle: 0.4 mm
Layer thickness: 0.25 mm
Print speed: 40 mm/s
Temperature: 220 C

These parts were used:
E3D V6 mount: http://repables.com/r/296/ (printed the pegs 4mm shorter than original)
E3D V6 layer fan shroud by dreyfusduke: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:614597
50x40x10 radial fans: http://www.aliexpress.com/item/5pcs-Black-Brushless-DC-Cooling-Blower-Fan-2-Wires-4010S-12V-0-15A-40x10mm/32314435053.html

remixed_from.title: 2-in-1 fan duct: extruder and filament cooler for E3D V6 and others

title: Fun duct on/off valve to material blowout remix

description.text:
I wanted a version with a small extension to allow for adjustment without needing an extra tool. All I did is take the sketch used for creating the extruded cut and did a boss extrude of 7mm. Then used a 1mm fillet all around. This is just a remix of the on/off valve.

Update:
The main part of this was too thin for my taste, so I thickened it to 2mm, gave it some alignment tabs and made it wrap around the heat sink of the cold end more similar to the stock V6 injection molded piece. It now stays in place. It was too loose and fragile before. I also opened up the hole a little bigger for the valve to require less adjustment after printing.

comments.author: thehebs

comments.text:
Really like this design.
I want to replace the M5 threaded rods on my i3 rework with lead screws and brass nuts with 4 mount screws like yours.
Have you checked the i3 rework 1.5 from emotion-Tech?
They use the same type of brass nuts but they mount them with M3 nuts at the bottom. This makes sense since the brass nut and the M3 screws are at the top. In your parts the plastics are kept in place just with screws. If the mount holes won't print correctly the plastics will fall down.
Also in emotion-Tech parts there are zip ties to hold tight the plastic around the LM8UU. I already broke mine while tightening the X belt.
I like emotion-Tech's design but I don't want to reverse the X motor body.
I would edit yours but I don't know how to use SketchUp. I could if they were OpenSCAD files.
comments.author: hackermagnet

comments.text: I actually addressed this concern with the original designer of these (i just remixed to accommodate the brass nuts). He assured me he had been using the current design (nuts on top with screws threaded into plastic) for multiple years. I had the same concerns as you; there is constant pressure upward on a nut that is mounted with screws into plastic. After trying this setup, I actually feel that it is extremely sturdy.

author: thehebs

description.text:
These pieces lock to rails on a saddle and allow a small mini pump to be placed sideways under the saddle instead of attaching it to the bike frame. One of the designs is an adapter piece that can be used to bolt in a rack for pump. There racks that come with pumps are usually designed to fit drinking bottle places on bike frames.

Couple of different versions position the pump differently under the saddle. Finally I ended up using the adapter version, so I was also able to connect and disconnect my Otrlieb saddle bag to its rails at the same time.

NOTE: The adapter piece doesn't have as quite wide spacing as the standard drinking bottle bolts have, but it can be modified as such if needed.
My pump holder still fit it just fine (as they always seem to have some tolerance to allow for different bikes frames that are not made exactly to spec).

I printed from black PLA with 0.8mm sides and 20% infill. That seems just barely strong enough for the job. I assume versions would require higher infill to stay intact.

To put things together, you need two M3 bolts and nuts to tighten top and bottom halves together around the rails on your saddle. Other sizes of bolts and nuts can be used, but M3 nuts will tightly fit in the slots in the design.

If using the adapter version, then two additional bolts and nuts are needed for attaching a pump rack to the adapter. Pumps usually come with those. I just used M4 sized bolts and nuts for that.

remixed_from.author: Tech2C
remixed_from.title: E3D v6 Bowden X-carriage mount Prusa i3

title: Rapide Lite 200 E3D-V6 Bowden extruder retrofit

description.text:
So, I was quite unhappy with the extruder that came with the Rapide. Particularly the cooling - on both the workpiece, and the heatsink (which itself was quite poor).

I decided to retrofit what is quite possibly the best hot end on the market today for a little more reliability and increased ease of part repair/replacement.

In my instance, I printed the entire setup in PETG as I didn't have ABS, and don't care much for the smell as PETG has the same heat toerances with zero odour.

The weight savings is quite substantial even without the extruder motor, the new configuration is almost over 1/3 less in weight. I've added a SeeMeCNC EZ Struder as my cold-end extruder, however there are many other bowden style extruders you can use in its place. Everything works like a charm - way better than the original print settings, I can now increase my print speed much higher, and still get better results than before.

The main bracket that holds the Hot End was originally designed by another user - Credit is due there as the original design was made by Tech2C http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:547706 Because I really liked his design, I copied it from scratch to fit the hole pattern in my configuration.
Printed everything at 20% infill @ 0.2mm layer height using PETG Natrual filament. Hole sizes are for M4 screws and Nuts, the screw for the fan duct is M3 with a hole for a Nyloc washer at the back.

author: CallJoe

description.text:
This is a test of hidden text.  
Hold it up to the light to read it.  
(Or you could just look at the slicer output...)  
we'll see if this thing used in conjunction with the phrase: "If I show you what it says, you have to show me what it says..." is effective.

slice with: 20% fill (pattern doesn't matter)
single top and bottom layers
diaphragm every 3 layers
diaphragm thickness 2 layers
print in white. How to make your own:
In SketchUp, use the 3-d Text to write what you want.
Then you build a cubic rectangle around it, it should be 2mm thicker than the text, so you have 3 layers below the text, the text, and than 3 layers above the text.
That makes the internal letters hollow, but the outer shell solid.
